comments.commentBody:
I'm glad too see the NY Times interested in MMA, for for its own credibility it should really ask someone who knows about the sport to write about it.

This list is mostly ridiculous. CM Punk is not even a fighter. He is 0-0-0. Brock Lesnar was a decorated collegiate wrestler and a freak athlete who arrived as a major superstar and quickly became the world champion. He looked and fought like the Hulk. CM Punk is a joke and is continuously trolled by MMA fans wherever he appears. He will have 1 or 2 fights in the UFC against other non fighters and will disappear.

Demitrious Johnson?? Really?? Do you even know who he is or did you just pull his name off of wikipedia? The guy is so unpopular his PPV keep on breaking mediocrity levels.

Anderson Silva.... Hum, the guy is over 40, is on suspension for a while, has 0-2 and 1 DQ on his last 3 fights AND WAS NEVER A BIG STAR OR PPV DRAW EVEN AT HIS PRIME. A future star... Ok, whatever.

I'm glad you didn't waste your time with no-potential rookies like Joanna Jędrzejczyk, Paige Vanzant or Sage Northcutt!
So what is your proposal for fighting and defeating ISIS?

Yes, let's be realistic. They may shout and bellow but ISIS doesn't have the capability to threaten us. That's realistic. They're 20-30k strong. No navy, no air force, and barely arms to control the little land they have. We're 370 million strong and a world away.

I don't pretend to know all the solutions but we do know what DOESN'T work. Sending thousands of American troops to the MIddle East as ISIS members melt back into the civilian population. A guerilla war that bleeds the US of our young men and women, billions of dollars as an occupying force and whose effectiveness fades as we eventually leave the country only to have these terrorist thugs reassert themselves. Repeat and rinse.

As someone who considers themselves liberal, I completely agree.  These reactions that say we cannot react with force just beg the question, then what do we do? Are we willing to live with an extremist faction that now controls substantial land in two countries, systemically enslaves and rapes people, commits genocidal actions, destroys intellectual ideals, reduces to rubble our shared archaeological heritage, oppresses the rights of women and men alike? Oh yea, and they have committed three international incidents in the past two weeks that equate to mass murder of civilians.  The left leaning strategies I have heard (an air only war, containment, cutting off funding, etc) sound like very marginal efforts in crushing ISIS.

The NYT Editorial board lives in a liberal dreamland. ISIS and Muslim extremists want to kill everyone of us. Wake up. there is no where to flee. We should not be reactionary but we must be realistic.
If you don't like it here you could always move to the suburbs.

Legitimate question: has the author of this article ever watched a second of MMA? Because reading this laughable list tells me to the contrary.

Jon Jones "inheriting" Ronda's aura? HAHAHAHAHA. Jones was UFC champ and P4P #1 in the world before Rousey was even a thing.

CM Punk will wash out with a quickness. Dude has ZERO fighting or training experience and is almost 40. What are you even talking about? Are you serious?

Anderson Silva is done. One more fight max and then off to the sunset. He looked visibly slower and diminished in the Diaz fight, and Weidman cleaned his clock twice. He KO'd Silva in the second fight, too. while in the clinch in the first round, but Silva woke up when he hit the mat. Plus the only times he broke the bank was the second Chael fight.

As for Rousey, she lost because she simply had a gigantic skill disadvantage vs. Holm. A second fight would be no different, but you'll see that soon enough.

LOL NYTimes should stick with shilling for corporate interests. You know nothing of MMA, this is an embarrassing read.

I've followed Holly Holm's career a bit as she's local. Albuquerque is very proud of her and certainly pleased with her win. It was surprising, but she's a hard worker and she had good training and support from a top gym.

I've only seen replays of the first round and read a few descriptions. Seems that Holly outfought and outclassed Ronda at every turn. I'd heard that Rousey was unbeatable. But every time you hear that it's time to get some money down on the other side.

Ronda had no clue what was waiting for her in that octagon, and she had no answers. The rematch should be great.

Rousey is no Mike Tyson. Her 12 vs his 40, Really!!! You Gus are overreaching with analogies like this.

Maybe if she hadn't believed her own press she would have shown her opponent more respect. The bravado at the weigh, over the top. The unsportsmanlike behavior of not touching gloves before the bell, big mistake.
No one can fill Ronda's shoes. I believe even with the loss Ronda will continue to  lead the UFC fan base that she has attracted and will capture the attention of the media, film and TV.
One day your facetiousness will be replaced by a true longing for the return of someone actually interested in the hard work of governing this city.

What bothers me about de Blasio is his vociferous resentment of the tax base and encouragement of this resentment with his constituency (I do not consider myself one of his constituents ~ I am a member of the tax base). Instead of bringing the city together, he is exacerbating the "Tale of Two Cities."

This is patently absurd.  Most whites are not the "1%"--they are the middle class, along with middle class Latinos, Asians and blacks who, with the 1%, pay all the taxes that support the indigent who don't pay any taxes.

I resigned my Life Membership in the National Rifle Association when they went so far off the deep end, I no longer wanted to be associated with them.   Please consider, at least, identifying yourself as an independent.

"Where are the Saudis? They have a very capable military"

They are in Yemen, and not so capable since they are failing even there.

The Saudis are a great example of that overused phrase, paper tiger.

Saudis do not have a capable military.

http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2015/05/26/why-saudi-arabias-yemen-w...

ISIS is rooted in the Saudi version of Islam - an extremely violent and mid-evil branch of the Sunni sect. It started in the 1700s in Saudi Arabia, it has been expanding ever sense.

The royal family in Saudi is scared out of their mind by these extremists, so they give them money to 'emigrate' to wealthy western nations and pay for their Mosques, to be built in those countries, not Saudi Arabia.

Seriously, you think this is about oil? Yes, oil made Saudi rich, and with that it made the Wahhabism branch of Sunni much more powerful and able to spread around the world. Saudi's ruling class has been spreading Wahhabism around the world for decades.

Where are the Saudis? They have a very capable military, thanks to billions of dollars' worth of the latest tanks and airplanes that we sold them. ISIS is destabilizing every country in the region. Are they not concerned about their Sunni bad boy brethren chopping off heads and blowing up airplanes and nightclubs?

W Bush likes to pose with the jeweled sword they gave him, and even Democrats won't criticize them, or ask them to make any sacrifices. It's become clear that both our government and those in the Arabian Peninsula value the lives of young Saudis more than our own soldiers, whose views of valorous warfare have been shaped by ads during NFL games, paid for by the taxpayer.

The other little problem is that the Saudis are funding ISIS themselves, indirectly or via wealthy individuals such as Al Waleed.

Let's take a timeout. The French can blow off some steam, even if they end up where the British, the Turks, and we Americans did. Alternatively, we could go ahead and kill a few hundred thousand more Iraqis and Syrians, resulting in enormous suffering in an already global warming dessicated region, while the world struggles with their refugees.

This is all just another consequence of oil companies and armaments manufacturers running our once proud nation. Until we stand up to them, we, and the whole world, will lose, big time.

Good point! I don't like politics nor do I have any wise opinions or comments on any political issues, not even on my own country's political policies. But when it comes to Xinjiang, the wording becames"embraced extremism out of despair". I mean really, "out of despair". It  just doesn't sound very unbiased and friendly to a Chinese person.

I always read new Sinosphere articles mentioning violence in Xinjiang to see if they include the obligatory explanation for terrorist killings as being necessary due to Uyghur despair and oppression. As does this article by Mr Wu.

Generally, NY Times does not get China, their reporting usually including snarky criticisms of the little snippets of life their stringers see. I spend a lot of time in China for work and pleasure and have spent time in Xinjiang, too. NYT misrepresents life on the ground and distorts the history of the region.

Their reporting from China is so bad one is not blamed for conjecturing reasons such as the corporation being so miffed over their banishment by the party that they are resolved to always paint pictures of sadness and incompetence - my experiences there is that Chinese are, on a daily basis, happier than we are.

Unfortunately, in my neighborhood we hear lots of gunshots, lots of helicopters searching for perpetrators, and lots of news that yet another (black) man has been shot and killed. And that teenagers are being shot. And that children are being caught in crossfire.

Maybe stopping and frisking for guns isn't so bad. Racial profiling? We're not the midwest or the South; here in Brooklyn, virtually all violent crime is being committed by young black men of the trash class.

White trash we can talk about. How about black trash? Everyone in the neighborhood can tell the working father of two or the young man going to Brooklyn Tech from the guys who hang out on the corner and the guys with Virginia and New Hampshire license plates who visit twice or three times a week. Watch them come out of their cars and urinate on the apartment building wall. You'll know whom to stop and frisk.

Your statement that Stop and frisk is unconstitutional is in accurate. The courts did not find the policy of stop an frisk unconstitutional; rather they found that that the way it was implemented was unconstitutional modifications.

Most white New Yorkers have never understood how humiliating and devastating the stop and frisk policies were for African-Americans. That unconstitutional policy was the main reason black New Yorkers voted for the mayor in the numbers they did and why they will continue to support him. Unfortunately, that willful ignorance and inability to "see" the lives of those without privilege will ultimately destroy us a city and doom us a nation.

Mr. Deblasio has angered the group that pays the freight. If white NYers feel they are being ignored they will find a candidate they want He seems to have forgotten n the old line - he who pays the piper calls the tune.

You can fool some people some of the time, as I guess you are hoping to do.  First, when was De Blasio elected?  In 2008?  Not quite.  But the chart you cherry pick from shows that all seven categories of major felonies have fallen from 2000 to 2014.  Two have gone up from 2008 to 2014, rape slightly though the 2014 number is lower than it was in 2010, 2011, 2012 and 2013, and felony assault more significantly but it turns out that 2008, 2009 and 2010 were lower than any years before or after.  Grand larceny is down minimally, burglary is down substantially following a long trend, robbery is also down substantially and as you noted and dismissed, so is murder.  Are you saying that burglary and robbery aren't crimes that count when talking about people feeling safe?  Do you realize that a significant proportion of felony assaults are between people who know each other such as domestic violence, whereas burglary and robbery seldom are?  I think most people worry a lot more about the crimes committed on them by people they don't know than they do about drunken fights with their friends, family members and neighbors.
Sorry, you are just wrong.  De Blasio is an "advocate" looking to pontificate on a national stage, who doesn't have have the appetite or backbone to govern this city.
De Blasio's policies have made life more dangerous for minorities, as ending Stop & Frisk inspires young men to start packing heat again. The victims are mostly young people of color.

This wildly unfocused diatribe fails to address the fact that Mayor de Blasio is in way in over his head and has neither appetite nor ability to govern this complicated city.  Most voters have figured that out, hence the results of this very realistic poll.

Jack 47 was very specific and he also mentioned a major accomplishment of the current administration: free pre-K for tens of thousands of children and their families. This is a giant step forward as would be evident to anyone not imprisoned by their off-putting prejudice and churlishness.
Actually while most Staten Islanders (borough with lowest crime rate) dislike deBlasio, the mayor has a cordial relationship with the Island's republican elected officials.

Nice to see that the mayor is coachable and is making the needed outreach and availability.

Still I would not lose much sleep about losing the vote of someone who thinks taking on charters schools (that seem to push the hard to teach out the door), and stop and frisk as "the little things."

"All I hear about is universal pre-k!" Me too! I live in Flatbush and see a multitude of toddlers every day.

Do these voters miss Mayor Mike? The Oligarch whose legacies are "poor doors" and the soot-colored, 100-story "safe houses" on Central Park South his peers buy up to launder their money? (btw, I do the annual homeless count, and Mayor Mike was famous for sending cops to scoop up those sheltering outdoors so we couldn't count them. Or are these folks not angry for the homeless but AT them?)

If I were mayor, and a staffer brought me this survey and I realized that the jury pool in Staten Island that "coughed up" the 12, who could not indict a white police officer for an illegal choke hold ON CAMERA that led to Eric Garner's death ON CAMERA, had turned against me, I would know I am on the side of the angels, and I would sleep like a baby.

It says here his coalition is still largely intact. It's because they're finally getting "free stuff" like the right to walk home from a restaurant without getting unconstitutionally thrown on the hood of a car at the whim of the men in blue.

This was a "telephone" survey. Was it all land-lines, or were people born after 1950 included?
Sorry if you are opposed to effective education and in favor of privileging the incompetents protected by the teachers union.

Charter schools are filled with children whose parents take the time to shop around for publicly funded schools that aren't public schools. That means their kids might have an advantage: concerned parents.

Our public schools used to be places where students worked hard and got educated. In my mother's day, her parents would have stood for nothing less. When she cut school to see skinny Frank Sinatra sing, the principal called her in the next day and all my mother could do was wail, "Please don't tell my mother."

Nowadays we have far too many children who are products of their mothers' indiscriminate baby-making on the taxpayers' tab. They have not been spoken to, sung to, taught self-restraint or manners, and they are practically pre-lingual.

If you expect schoolteachers to educate them or even control them, you've another think coming. And that's what's wrong with our school system except that no one dares admit it. Because it would mean that for too many people, welfare has not operated as it was supposed to.

Even a few unruly kids make it almost impossible for the others to learn. Try teaching a classroom of them.

There's no mention of the relentless ad campaigns by charter schools to destroy public education and take down de Blasio . Night after night, how many millions do these ads cost? As a teacher in a public school teaching computer science on PCs that just turned 10 years old, it's heart-breaking and disgusting to the point of criminal. No wonder his approval is down. Hedge fund managers behind the private education movement, along with their best friend in Albany, is waging war against the elected leader of the city.

I agree.  Quinn is a detail-oriented administrator, and the city is one of the world's largest administration projects.  As I remember, her campaign was torpedoed by a Times piece claiming she shouted at her subordinates.  That's a pretty small sin, as sins go, and perhaps she has undergone anger management sessions since that time.

I don't believe that NYC is any worse off under De Blasio. Sure, if you already don't like the mayor, you are going to find some anecdotal evidence to the contrary, but that is true under any administration. However, I get the impression that he is largely ineffective. I'm pretty left of center socially, but I don't at all care for the progressive posturing and pandering to his base and varies other interests, such as the cab owners or hotel lobbies. At least with Bloomberg you always knew exactly what you had. You might not have agreed, but Bloomberg made logical decisions based on data. He was ultimately much more independent and effective, and that is what I'm looking for in a mayor. NYC came roaring back after 9/11, and De Blasio is still benefiting from that. I hope Quinn decides to give it another go.
Apparently you have never been to Brooklyn, the Bronx, Queens or Staten Island, where millions of middle class New Yorkers live.
Bloomberg *had* three terms.  But yeah, I wanted her, too.
I never felt that the mayor was talking to and working for all New Yorkers.

Literally everyone I know has turned against him, though not so much for the reasons stated in the article.  Rather the gripes I've heard (and share) tend to be about his overt pandering to the Police Union which entirely undermines his credibility as a reformer.  He comes off as an utter hypocrite, terrified in the face of police power and unwilling to insist on the changes he promised (and which swept him into power.)
